I slammed the door and grabbed a pen, scrawling his name on a piece of paper, over and over, until my hand cramped. My mind replayed every argument, every dismissive shrug, every broken promise. The more I wrote, the messier my handwriting became, until his name was nothing but a tangle of lines. I balled up the paper and threw it into the trash. 

Standing there, breathless and spent, I realized the rage had done something. It carved out a space where I could begin to feel other things—relief, even a little amusement at my own melodrama. Maybe, just maybe, this was progress.

Titanium tables holding cadavers were lined in rows in the stark, laboratory-like space. The sound of the overhead fluorescent lights flickering was the only indication of life. Dr. Halvorsen moved methodically, her gloved hands trembling ever so slightly as she adjusted the syringe in her grasp. Each body was a puzzle waiting to be solved, but tonight was different. As she leaned over the third table, the cadaver—a man in his forties, no visible trauma—seemed to twitch. She froze, heart pounding, and watched as the eyelids fluttered open. The security cameras caught her recoiling, dropping the syringe onto the polished floor. But what the footage missed was the sudden shift in the room’s temperature, the brief flicker of blue light in the man’s eyes. Dr. Halvorsen staggered back, staring at the impossible. The word echoed in her mind. She knew then that this was not a simple autopsy—this was a reckoning. And she, unwittingly, was at its center.

And I could snap you in two pieces and all. That’s what I told the mirror on the day it finally answered back. I’d spent years glaring into its silver depths, daring it to reflect something kinder, but it only ever sent back the same tired eyes, the same crooked smile. Until this morning, when my reflection smirked, cocked its head, and whispered, “You wouldn’t dare.”

I raised my fist, knuckles white. “Watch me.”

But the glass rippled, and suddenly my reflection stepped out, flesh and bone, smudged with starlight. I stumbled backwards, heart thundering, as she circled me with a predator’s grace. “I know all your secrets,” she purred. “All your fears.”

The air crackled between us. For a moment, I wanted to run. But I remembered every morning I’d survived, every shadow I’d faced. So I straightened, looked her square in the eye, and said, “Then you know I don’t break easy.”

She smiled, sharp as shattered glass. “Neither do I.”

The tension coiled between us like a live wire. Outside, our parents argued, their voices muffled and distant. I clenched my fists, anger bubbling up—anger at him, at them, at the cracked concrete floor beneath my feet. I took a step forward, but he didn’t flinch. Instead, he slid one of the comics across the floor toward me.

“Take it,” he whispered. “You need it more than I do.”

The rage drained from me, replaced by something heavier. I knelt down, picked up the battered comic, and sat beside him in silence. The storm above us raged on, but for the first time in weeks, we read together, letting the world outside fade away.

"It’s just a toy," my mother insisted, tucking the covers tight around me. But when the lights went out, I heard the soft clatter of its tiny shoes on the wooden floor.

One night, curiosity—or maybe defiance—got the better of me. I waited, eyes wide open, until the grandfather clock downstairs chimed three times. The doll’s head swiveled, glass eyes glinting in the moonlight. "You think you’re so strong?" I whispered, heart pounding.

The doll slid off the shelf, landing with a muffled thud. "Stronger than you think," it replied, voice as brittle as cracking china. I stood up, grabbed my flashlight, and faced it. "Let’s see who breaks first," I said, and in the darkness, the game began.

And I could snap you in two pieces and all. That’s what the old porcelain doll said, her voice coming from a hairline crack in her cheek. I stared back at her, arms trembling, uncertain if I should laugh or run. The attic was thick with dust, and every shadow seemed to lean in, listening. “You think you’re the one in control?” she continued, glassy eyes glinting. “You’re in my house now.”

My fingers tightened around the flashlight. “You’re just a toy,” I whispered, but my words sounded small.

Her painted mouth curled into a grin. “And yet you’re the one who’s afraid.”

A wind rose, rattling the windowpanes. The doll’s head swiveled, joints creaking. “There’s still time to leave. Or stay, and learn what old secrets I keep.”

Unable to move, I watched as she slid off the shelf, her tiny feet tapping on the wood. She looked up, waiting for my decision. The attic door slammed shut behind me.

I realized, too late, that some things are best left undisturbed. And sometimes, the most fragile things hold the greatest power.

And I could snap you in two pieces and all. The threat hung between us like a jagged icicle, glinting in the dim kitchen light. My sister, Liv, glared at me over the chessboard, her fingers wrapped around the black queen. I knew she’d never do it, but the fire in her eyes was real—wilder than I’d ever seen.

“You wouldn’t,” I challenged, but my voice wavered.

She smirked, shifting in her chair. “Watch me.”

Outside, the wind howled, rattling the windows. A storm was coming. Inside, a different storm brewed, one born of secrets and years of rivalry.

She moved her queen, toppling my last pawn. “Checkmate. You lose again.”

I clenched my fists. “It’s just a game.”

But Liv shook her head, her gaze softening. “It’s never just a game with us.”

The lights flickered, and for a moment, everything stilled—two sisters, locked in a silent battle, the weight of unspoken words pressing down on us. Outside, thunder roared.

Maybe she couldn’t snap me in two. But some days, it sure felt like she already had.

“You think you’re tough?” he spat, tossing a battered football between his hands. “Prove it.”

My heart pounded, but I stood my ground, staring into eyes that had seen too many seasons come and go. He’d always picked on the weakest, always demanded more than anyone could give. I took a step forward, my voice steady. “I’m not afraid of you.”

He smirked, a cruel twist of his lips. “We’ll see about that.”

Outside, rain battered the windows, but inside, the air was electric. I realized then it wasn’t about strength; it was about standing tall, refusing to break. No matter how much he tried to snap me, I’d bend, but I wouldn’t shatter.

“You think you’re tough?” the shadow taunted, its form stretching and shrinking with every step. I forced a laugh. “You don’t scare me.”

A chuckle, hollow and cold. “Maybe I should.”

I reached the end of the alley, light spilling into the darkness. The shadow hesitated, shrinking away from the glow. I turned. “You only have power over me here, in the dark. I choose the light.”

The shadow recoiled, dissolving as I stepped out. I realized then: fear lurks in darkness, but courage grows in the light.

And I could snap you in two pieces and all. That’s what Grandmother always said about the wishbones she kept in the old blue jar above the stove. Each one, she claimed, held a story—some sweet, some bitter, none ever the same. When I turned twelve, she handed me my first wishbone, brittle and yellowed with age. “Make a wish, child, but mind what you wish for. These bones remember.”

I closed my eyes, gripping the bone between my fingers. Around us, the kitchen clock ticked, slow and steady. I wished for courage—the sort Grandmother seemed to wear like a shawl. I felt the wishbone tremble, then snap cleanly in two. The room brightened, just for a second, as if sunlight had found its way through the rainclouds.

Grandmother smiled, her eyes twinkling. “A wish well made,” she said. I tucked my half of the wishbone into my pocket, the tiny fragment sharp but comforting. Years later, whenever I needed strength, I’d find it there, a small reminder that even the most fragile things can hold extraordinary power.

“Stop checking my phone,” Ella said, her voice low but sharp as a slice of winter air. Dylan froze, his thumb hovering above the glowing screen. Outside, the rain tapped a nervous code against the window. 

He looked up, guilt and something else flickering in his eyes. “I’m sorry. I just… I thought you were hiding something.”

Ella reached for the phone and tucked it into her pocket, her knuckles pale. “Everyone has a right to a secret, Dylan. Even me.” She turned away, but the silence between them was louder than the rain. 

Dylan wanted to protest, to explain the gnawing worry in his chest, but he knew he’d crossed a line. Instead, he watched Ella as she gathered her coat and keys, moving with quiet determination. 

“Where are you going?” he asked.

Ella paused in the doorway, her eyes softening for a moment. “To remember who I was before I let someone else’s fear define me.”

And then she was gone, leaving Dylan alone with his doubts and the echo of her words.

“I’m just tired. Stop being nosy,” she said, forcing a small smile.

But Liam watched her as she left the kitchen, suspicion growing. Ella’s secret was safe—for now. But she knew it wouldn’t be long before the truth would have to come out, no matter what it cost.

“I just worry about you,” she murmured, voice barely above a whisper.

Ella hugged the phone to her chest as if it could shield her from the conversation she knew was coming. The truth was, the messages weren’t dangerous, but they were hers. Private jokes with friends, dreams she didn’t want to share, little pieces of herself that felt too fragile to expose.

“Trust me, please,” Ella said.

Her mother studied her for a long moment, then sighed, turning back to the sink. “I do, Ella. I’m just learning how.”

Ella let out a breath she didn’t realize she’d been holding. She slid her phone into her pocket and reached for a new piece of bread. Silence hung between them, but it felt different now—softer, less heavy. Maybe, Ella thought, trust was something you built one small moment at a time.

And I could snap you in two pieces and all. That’s what the old willow whispered as I stood under its twisted branches, the wind pulling at my jacket. I laughed, nervous, thinking it was only the wind, but the voice came again, slow and heavy, thick with ancient sap. “You think you’re so tough, coming here with your axe. But I remember your grandfather, and your father before him. I watched them leave with splinters in their hands and shame in their eyes.”

I hesitated, glancing at the axe. Was it worth it, chopping down a tree that could speak? My knuckles turned white around the handle. “I have no quarrel with you,” I whispered.

The willow’s branches shivered. “Yet here you are.”

I stepped back, heart pounding. The tree’s roots curled, shifting the earth. “Go home,” it said softly, “before you become another story told beneath my leaves.”

I dropped the axe. Without looking back, I ran, the willow’s laughter rustling behind me. Even now, I can hear it in every storm: a warning, or perhaps, a promise.

And I could snap you in two pieces and all. That’s what she said, grinning at me across the warped linoleum table. Her hands were delicate, almost translucent in the flickering diner light, but her eyes were iron. I pretended to laugh, but inside I was cold. No one else seemed to notice, not the tired cook, not the truckers hunched over their coffee. Only me and her—the woman who’d followed me since midnight, whose footsteps always matched my own.

She slid a matchbox across the table. “Open it.”

Inside, a single tooth, polished and shining. I stared at it, unsure whether to scream or run.

“Next time, it won’t fit in the box,” she said. Her smile widened. “You owe me. Don’t forget.”

The bell above the door jingled, and she was gone, leaving only the matchbox and the shadow of her threat. I sat for a long time, listening to the hum of the neon sign, wondering if anyone would believe me—or if the next time, I wouldn’t be so lucky.

My knees shook, but I forced myself to meet his gaze. “But you won’t,” I said, gripping the worn-out sword at my side. The giant chuckled, a sound like boulders rolling down a hill. “You’re right. I won’t. Not if you answer my riddle.”

His eyes gleamed. “What walks on four legs at dawn, two at noon, and three in the evening?”

I hesitated. The answer danced at the edge of my mind, but fear clouded my thoughts. “A human,” I finally whispered. “Crawling as a child, walking as an adult, leaning on a cane in old age.”

The giant grinned, stepping aside. “You may pass.”

Relief flooded me. I crossed the bridge, heart pounding, promising myself I’d never doubt the power of words again.

And I could snap you in two pieces and all. That’s what the voice said, low and dry, as if it had uttered this threat a thousand times before. But in the flickering candlelight, the shadow on the wall shook, uncertain. I held my breath and didn’t move a muscle—my grandmother’s silver locket cold in my fist. 

The creature towering over me was not from any storybook, nor from my nightmares; it was all bone and bramble, a shape that borrowed from everything I’d ever feared. But I remembered what Grandpa told me: “Sometimes, the only thing that can snap is the fear itself.”

I straightened my back and let the locket fall open. The creature’s head cocked, its hollow eyes narrowing. The glint of old photo paper and the scent of lavender filled the room. The shadow shrank, shrinking further until it was nothing more than a line at my feet. 

I exhaled. The walls hummed. “You could try,” I whispered, voice steady. “But you won’t.” And with that, the last of the darkness seeped out of my room, leaving me with only the echo of bravery I never knew I had.

The scarecrow’s head cocked to the side, straw spilling from its sleeve as it raised a clawed hand. I remembered the stories: whoever faced the scarecrow at midnight would have their fate decided—courage or cowardice, reward or ruin. 

My fingers curled around the amulet in my pocket. It pulsed, warm against my skin.

Lightning flickered outside, and for a moment I saw my own reflection in the glass—smaller than I felt, but stronger than I seemed. The scarecrow hesitated. I stepped forward, pressing the amulet to its heart. The air shimmered, and the creature stilled, brittle arms dropping to its sides. 

“And yet, you didn’t,” I whispered. The threat faded with the moonlight, and I walked out stronger than I had entered, never looking back.

He opened his mouth, then closed it, as if weighing the cost of an answer. Outside, the city pulsed with life, horns blaring and lights flickering like restless thoughts. I steadied myself, bracing for whatever confession might come. The truth had been elusive for so long, woven into half-remembered stories and late-night phone calls. Now, in this cramped office, it pressed against us, demanding to be spoken. Jonah finally met my eyes. "I did what I had to do," he said, voice barely above a whisper. And in that moment, I realized that sometimes, understanding comes not from answers, but from the courage to ask.

instance_metrics.response: I suppose you were, weren’t you? The phrase flickered in my mind as I watched the lantern drift higher into the indigo night, carrying with it a scrap of paper and a wish I wasn’t sure I believed in. The festival crowd pressed around me, their laughter muffled by the hush of anticipation. Somewhere beyond the lanterns, you were watching too—perhaps from the mountain ridge, or maybe from the other side of memory. We had promised each other long ago to meet here, beneath the lanterns, if the world ever grew too heavy. Now, as my wish flickered among a thousand others, I wondered if you felt the same pull, the same ache for something lost and almost found. My heart beat a quiet rhythm of hope as I waited, eyes searching the shadows for your silhouette, for the answer I both feared and longed to find.

Mr. Valen had always been known as the town’s most enigmatic resident. Every morning, he would leave his ivy-wrapped cottage precisely at 6:47, carrying a battered leather briefcase that no one had ever seen opened. Children whispered that it contained maps to hidden worlds; old Mrs. Redding insisted she’d heard it ticking late at night.

On the first Thursday in June, a thick fog rolled in, swallowing the village’s edges. Mr. Valen paused at his gate, glancing up at the flickering streetlamp. From the mist emerged a small, shivering cat with emerald eyes. It looked up at him, unblinking, and meowed with a note of desperation.

Without a word, Mr. Valen knelt and opened his briefcase for the first time in public. Instead of papers or gadgets, it held a tiny velvet cushion and a silver bell. The cat leapt inside, curling up as if it had been expected all along. Mr. Valen snapped the case shut and vanished into the fog. The next morning, only the faint sound of a bell remained, echoing through the empty streets.

Mr. Pendleton was not the sort of man who drew attention, but that changed the day he arrived at the annual town bake-off wearing a neon pink tuxedo and carrying a pineapple upside-down cake carved in the shape of a ship. The judges gawked as he set down his masterpiece and proceeded to narrate the cake’s journey across the Seven Sugary Seas. The crowd, at first skeptical, soon found themselves swept along by his tale of gingerbread pirates and marzipan whales.

As the story sailed on, the cake itself seemed to shimmer, and a faint scent of salt and adventure wafted through the hall. By the time Mr. Pendleton concluded with a dramatic cannonball made of candied cherries, the townsfolk were convinced they heard distant waves.

The judges, unable to decide if they were hungrier or more entranced, awarded him both first prize and a standing invitation to return next year—on the condition he brought a new story, and perhaps, a parrot made of spun sugar.

Mr. Lowell’s garden was the talk of the cul-de-sac, but no one ever saw him tending it. The roses bloomed in impossible colors, the tulips chimed softly when the wind passed by, and every full moon, blue fireflies hovered just above the petunias. Neighbors suspected trickery, or perhaps some newfangled technology, but curiosity was always outmatched by the peculiar sense of unease that clung to Mr. Lowell’s fence.

One rainy afternoon, a soccer ball sailed over the fence, drawing young Emma to the forbidden gate. She found Mr. Lowell kneeling among the peonies, whispering to them in a language she did not know. He looked up, eyes glinting green, and smiled. “Every garden needs secrets,” he said, handing her the ball. As Emma turned to leave, she glimpsed a tiny figure—a rosebud with arms and legs—waving goodbye from beneath a leaf. She never spoke of what she saw, but her own garden began to bloom a little brighter after that day.

Mr. Finch had never believed in second chances, but when a battered envelope arrived at his doorstep, postmarked from a city he’d tried hard to forget, he reconsidered. Inside was a faded photograph: himself and a friend, grinning atop a Ferris wheel under a sapphire sky. Scribbled on the back were the words, “Meet me at the old pier. Midnight.”

That night, curiosity and nostalgia propelled Mr. Finch through the foggy streets to the abandoned pier. There, the Ferris wheel—long silent—creaked to life, lights twinkling like distant stars. As he stepped into a swaying carriage, a familiar laugh echoed in the darkness. The wheel began to turn, lifting him into the night and into the possibility of forgiveness, friendship, and the unburdening of secrets best shared high above a sleeping town.

Mr. Caliban was known for his peculiar habit of collecting shadows. Every evening, as the sun dipped behind the old clock tower, he would stroll through the cobblestone alleys, a small, silver net swinging at his side. He caught them gently—dog shadows, bicycle shadows, even the long, lonesome shadow of the lamplighter at dusk. Each night, he’d carry his collection home, releasing them into his attic, where they danced silently on the walls until dawn.

One night, a particularly bold shadow—a fox’s—refused to be caught. It darted and weaved, leading Mr. Caliban through twisting streets and forgotten courtyards. At the edge of town, the fox’s shadow leapt into a pool of moonlight, transforming into a real fox with eyes like midnight. It beckoned him forward, and without hesitation, Mr. Caliban followed, vanishing into the silvery glow. From that night on, no one saw him again, but sometimes, when the moon is high, a new shadow joins the others dancing in his attic, wild and free.

The clock on the wall behind me was loud, and I tapped my foot as fast as the second hand moved, scrolling through NuLife’s social media aimlessly, not to digest the curated perfection but to keep my mind from fraying. The comments were a blur: #NewYou #ForeverYoung #NuLifeGlow. I double-tapped a video of a woman morphing from gray and wrinkled to smooth and bright, her eyes shining with something that might have been hope or something else entirely. I wondered if she remembered who she was before. 

A notification popped up. “Your application for NuLife’s pilot program has been approved.” My finger hovered above the screen. I hadn’t applied, had I? I scrolled back through my messages—nothing. My heart pounded in sync with the clock’s tick. Someone out there, someone with access, wanted me in. The screen flickered, reflecting my face—tired, uncertain, hopeful. I stared at the clock as its hands seemed to slow, as if inviting me to step outside of time. I pressed “Accept” before I could think. The ticking stopped. The room grew quiet, and for the first time in months, I wondered what I was about to become.

The woods around him rustle with unseen lives; he wonders if any of them witnessed what just transpired. He tucks the sword into its battered sheath, feeling the weight of his actions settle into his bones. He can’t stay here. The trees lean in as if listening, but offer no counsel. He starts walking toward the river, boots squelching in the moss, the coppery tang of the night air sharp in his nose. Somewhere behind him, the world he knew is ending, but the sword is steady in his hand. He walks on, into darkness, into whatever comes next.

Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then. She welcomed the heat in her chest, the wild pounding of her heart, the way her hands shook with every remembered slight. She let the memories roll over her, each one sharpening her anger until it blazed. The broken promises, the absence when she needed him, the way her voice was never quite heard. 

Tonight, she would not swallow her pain. She stormed through her apartment, throwing open windows, letting the cold night air bite her skin. It felt good—real. She screamed, once, loud and long, and the sound startled her cat into hiding under the couch. 

By morning, her throat was raw, her eyes puffy. But her mind felt clearer. The weight on her chest lightened. She was still angry, but the rage was no longer something to be feared. It was something to be used, forged into resolve. She made coffee, sat in the sunlight, and wrote a list of everything she would do differently. Getting over it wasn’t about forgetting. It was about letting herself feel every dark thing until it passed, and she could finally move on.

Or maybe getting consumed with rage was part of getting over it … Fine then. He clenched his fists until his knuckles turned white, feeling the storm inside him grow. The world seemed to shrink to the pinpoint of his fury—every slight, every betrayal, every whispered insult echoing in his mind. For once, he didn't try to push it away; instead, he let the anger surge, burning away the numbness that had settled in his chest for weeks.

He marched outside into the biting wind, eyes stinging with unshed tears. Each step pounded his frustration into the frozen ground. When he reached the edge of the woods, he stopped and, with a guttural yell, hurled a stone into the thicket. The sound was small, but it echoed in the silence.

Afterwards, the fire waned, leaving a strange calm. He breathed—really breathed—for the first time in days. The anger hadn't solved anything, but it had cracked open the shell of misery, letting something else in. Maybe tomorrow he'd talk to her. Maybe tomorrow he'd try to explain. For now, it was enough to feel alive again, even if it burned.

I tore it in half, then again, watching each piece flutter to the floor like scorched leaves. 

The apartment felt too small for anger, but I paced anyway, letting every step echo my resentment. I thought of her laughter, how easily it used to fill this space. Now, silence pressed in, broken only by the sound of paper tearing and my ragged breaths. 

By midnight, exhaustion replaced fury. I was empty, but lighter. I swept up the fragments, promising myself that this was the last time I’d let the past dictate my night. Tomorrow, I’d start fresh. Tonight, I’d let rage run its course, and in the morning, maybe I’d find a little peace.

I let all the angry words I never said tumble out in a hoarse whisper, filling the empty car. Each accusation, each bitter memory, spilled into the confined space until the air felt thick. I screamed, just once—a raw, jagged sound swallowed by the storm outside.

"Stop checking my phone," Ella said, sliding the device out of Ben’s hands. He looked up from the glowing screen, a sheepish grin flickering across his face. "Sorry, it just buzzed, and I thought it might be important."

She tucked the phone into her backpack, zipping it shut. The fog was thick along the hiking trail, blurring the trees into shadowy pillars. "I told you, I’m expecting something. Can you trust me for once?"

Ben shrugged, kicking at a stone. "It’s not that I don’t trust you. It’s just... things have been weird since last week."

Ella stopped walking. Her breath made little clouds in the cold air. "Weird how?"

"You’re always texting, and you never tell me who it is."

She hesitated. "I didn’t want to worry you. My mom’s been getting those calls again."

He stared at her, the tension draining from his shoulders. "Why didn’t you say?"

Ella glanced over her shoulder, as if the fog might swallow them whole. "Because I’m scared. And I didn’t want you to be."

For a moment, silence settled between them. Then Ben took her hand. "We’ll get through this. Together."

"Stop checking my phone," Ella said. Her voice was unusually sharp, slicing through the lazy afternoon sunlight streaming onto the porch. Max, sprawled on the faded cushions beside her, barely flinched.

"I was just—"

"I know what you were just," she interrupted. "You don’t trust me."

Max sat up, rubbing his eyes. He didn’t want to admit it, but she was right. Ever since the messages from that unknown number started coming, he’d felt a gnawing suspicion. It wasn’t jealousy—at least, that’s what he told himself—it was worry.

Ella took a deep breath, her fingers drumming a nervous rhythm on the armrest. "If you really want to know, I’ll tell you," she said quietly. "But you have to promise not to freak out."

He nodded, heart thumping.

"Those messages—" she began, and then faltered, glancing at the willow tree at the end of the yard. "They’re from my sister. The one we don’t talk about. She’s back. She wants me to meet her."

Max exhaled slowly. Suddenly, the world felt dangerous and new.

"Stop checking my phone," Ella said. Her tone was icy, but her hands trembled as she plucked the device from Sam’s grasp. The old clock on the wall ticked louder in the silence that followed.

Sam stood, his face flushed. "I’m just worried, Ella. You’ve been getting those weird messages every night. You won’t tell me what they’re about."

Ella hugged the phone to her chest. "It’s not what you think. Honestly."

He paced the length of the living room, stopping by the window. Outside, the street was empty and dark. "Then what is it? Are you in trouble?"

Ella hesitated, then held out the phone. "Fine. Read the last text."

Sam took it, scanning the message: ‘Meet me at the old pier. Midnight. Come alone.’

He looked up, his voice barely a whisper. "Who is this from?"

Ella’s eyes glistened. "My brother. But he’s supposed to be dead."

"Stop checking my phone," Ella said, snatching it from Mia’s hands. The glow of the screen flashed across Ella’s anxious face. Mia raised her hands in surrender.

"Hey, sorry. I just thought it was mine," Mia lied, glancing nervously at the locked notification still visible on Ella’s phone: ‘Meet me at the corner, midnight. Don’t tell anyone.’

Ella shoved the phone into her pocket, her lips tight. The air in the tiny apartment was heavy with secrets. Mia took a deep breath. "You know you can trust me, right?"

Ella only nodded, avoiding Mia’s eyes as she busied herself with the dishes. The silence stretched, broken only by the clatter of plates.

Finally, Mia spoke. "If you’re in trouble… or if you need help—"

Ella’s shoulders tensed. "I can handle it. Just… please don’t ask."

Mia watched her friend, fear twisting in her gut. Something was very wrong, and she wondered if Ella’s secrets might soon become her own.

Several brooding thoughts and a few pristine angles later, I switch off the engine and call Jordan back. The phone rings twice, then three times, before she answers, her voice tight with expectation. I hesitate, glancing at the abandoned gas station in the rearview mirror. “I’m here,” I say, feigning confidence I don’t feel. 

“You said you’d be here an hour ago.” Her words push through the static, brittle as glass. 

I stare at the map crumpled on my passenger seat, the red inked circle around a town whose name I have never spoken aloud. “Got caught up,” I manage, “but I’m ready now.”

She sighs, and in that simple exhale, something fragile slips between us. “Are you sure?”

The sun dips behind storm clouds. I tighten my grip on the steering wheel, feeling the weight of every choice that led me here. “I’m not sure about anything except that I have to see this through.”

Jordan is silent, but I know she’s listening. The road ahead trembles with possibility. “Then drive,” she whispers. I do, leaving behind all that was safe for everything that might be real.

instance_metrics.response: Thanks for being part of his community! That’s what the note on the welcome basket said, perched on the stoop of the little blue house. Polly crouched down, examining the basket, suspicious of the handwritten tag and the slightly wilted petals on the bouquet. She’d moved in only yesterday—nobody should know her yet. But as she reached for the basket, a faint giggle echoed from the hedges. Polly spun around, catching a glimpse of a small, round face peering through the leaves, gone in a flash. Unsure whether to laugh or to lock all her doors, Polly carried the basket inside, where she found a second note: “Find us in the garden at midnight. Wear blue. Bring an open mind.” She considered tossing the basket in the trash. But as the sun set and the wind whispered through the eaves, curiosity won. At midnight, Polly stepped into her backyard, wrapped in a navy cardigan. The garden glimmered with fireflies—and there, in a circle of mushrooms, her neighbors waited, smiling, holding lanterns that glowed with an otherworldly light. "Welcome," they said, "to the community you never knew you needed."

Thanks for being part of his community! That’s what the email said, arriving one morning with no sender address and an odd, flickering font. Emily frowned, unsure what ‘his’ community meant. So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The woman behind the counter looks up, her eyes a swirl of cobalt and chartreuse, the colors shifting like an oil spill. She smiles, though her lips do not move. Outside, thunder mutters. “Old enough to remember when this city was forests and rivers,” she replies, her voice echoing twice in Ben’s head.

He shivers, clutching his umbrella tighter. “That’s… a long time.”

She nods, fingers tracing invisible patterns on the countertop. “I watched the first brick laid for Main Street. I listened to the speeches when the clock tower was raised. And I saw the last wolf run between the birches.”

Ben blinks. “Are you—are you joking?”

She leans in, eyes glimmering brighter. “Why do you think no one remembers what was here before?”

A silence grows between them, thick with old secrets. Ben’s heart thuds. He wonders, suddenly, if he’s the first to ask, or simply the first to listen.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The girl sitting across from him sips her coffee, glancing at the rain-streaked window. “If you mean in years, I suppose you could say nineteen.”

Ben laughs. “Suppose?”

She shrugs, a small smile curling her lips. “I measure time differently. I’m older in dreams than in days. Some nights, I’m ancient. Other mornings, I feel like I was born with the sunrise.”

He considers this, tapping his fingers on the mug. “So, you’re a poet.”

She shakes her head. “Just someone who’s lived a hundred lives in one.”

Outside, thunder rolls. Ben feels the shape of her words linger in the air. He realizes he’s not sure what he’s more curious about: her age, or the lifetimes she carries in her eyes.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The old man rubs his chin thoughtfully, peering at the flickering candle between them. “Well, I suppose that depends on how you measure.”

Ben grins. “In years. You know, like normal people.”

The man chuckles, a low, gravelly sound. “If you count only the years I’ve been called by this name, then 74. But if you count all the lives I’ve lived—well, that’s a much longer story.”

Ben raises an eyebrow, intrigued. “All the lives?”

The man nods, eyes shining with mischief. “I’ve been a sailor, a baker, a thief. I’ve been young and old, rich and poor. Sometimes I wonder if I’m more memories than man.”

Outside, wind rattles the window, and Ben leans in closer, suddenly eager to hear every impossible word.

So how old are you?” Ben asks.

Mara’s lips twitch as she glances down at her weathered hands. “Let’s just say I’m old enough to remember when this street was still a dirt path.”

Ben snorts. “That’d make you, what, a hundred?”

Mara laughs, her eyes crinkling at the corners. “Give or take a few decades.”

He leans forward, curiosity sparkling. “What was it like back then?”

She sighs, memories flickering in her gaze. “Quieter. The nights were darker, but the stars were brighter. People took time to listen. Even to old ladies who claim to remember too much.”

Ben smiles. “I’d like to listen.”

Mara nods, and as the kettle whistles, she begins her story, her voice weaving the past into the present.

"So how old are you?" Ben asks.

The figure across the table blinks, the motion almost mechanical, as if trying on the gesture for the first time. "I suppose that depends," it replies, voice as smooth as polished stone. "Do you mean this body, or the time I have traveled?"

Ben shifts uneasily in his chair, not sure if the stranger is joking. The café around them hums with normalcy, but this conversation feels like a crack in the world. "Both, I guess?" he manages.

"This body is seventeen years, six months, and twelve days old. But my journey began in a different age, before electricity, before iron ships, before the world spun so quickly. I have seen empires rise from dust and fall to it again."

Ben laughs nervously. "So, you’re a historian?"

The figure’s lips quirk in an almost-smile. "Something like that. Would you like to hear about the day the sky turned green?"

Ben hesitates, then nods, drawn by the gravity of a story he can’t quite believe.

The eunuch draws his bow again and aims for another passerby. No one notices the trembling in his hands, the sweat beading his brow beneath the elaborate headdress. The city square is full of laughter and trade, unaware of the silent predator perched above the awning. Each arrow is a message, each target chosen for a reason known only to the palace’s shadowed corridors.

He finds his next mark: a merchant’s son, oblivious as he counts copper coins. The eunuch’s breath steadies. His mind flickers back to the whispered promises the empress made, the threat of the dungeon, the glimmer of escape. The bowstring creaks. He releases. The arrow whistles through the market’s cacophony, embedding itself in the stall beside the boy’s hand.

The crowd erupts in panic. Guards shout. The eunuch slips away into the maze of rooftops, his mission unfinished. In the end, it was never about the boy, or the coins, or even the empress. It was about the message: that no one is untouchable. Not in this city. Not while the eunuch watches from above.

The eunuch draws his bow again and aims for another passerby. This time, his eyes fix upon a girl balancing baskets of figs atop her head. The crowd surges around her, oblivious to the silent threat above. He inhales, remembering the prophecy scrawled in blood on the palace wall: 'The third arrow mends what the first two break.'

His release is swift, arrow slicing through the humid afternoon air. The shaft lands squarely at the girl’s feet, sending figs tumbling but leaving her unscathed. She freezes, then stoops to retrieve the arrow. In its fletching is folded a scrap of silk, a warning only she can read: 'Run, the palace hunts you.'

As she vanishes into the alley, the eunuch melts into the shadows. He is not the monster they claim; his arrows have always been messengers, not murderers. He draws his hood tighter, knowing tomorrow he will be forced to choose a side. The city is changing, and so is he.

The eunuch draws his bow again and aims for another passerby. His robes are stained with dust, his face a mask of impassivity as the arrow nocks silently against the string. The crowd in the narrow alley below is thick—no one notices the shadow above them, nor the glint of steel in the fading sunlight. He inhales, holds, and then lets fly. The arrow whistles, striking the cobblestones beside an old woman’s heel. She stumbles, yelps, and the crowd parts around her. 

He grits his teeth, not at the miss, but at the memory it conjures: the Emperor’s order, the betrayal that left him voiceless and alone. Each arrow is a prayer for forgiveness he knows will not come. As the city guards scan the rooftops, he disappears into the labyrinthine city, bow slung low, arrows dwindling. He wonders, not for the first time, if redemption is possible—or if he is doomed to haunt the city as its silent, unseen retribution.

He releases. The arrow flits past the nobleman, slicing a ribbon from his hat. The crowd gasps. The eunuch melts back into the shadows, heart pounding. Each shot is a warning, a reckoning for those who think themselves safe. Tonight, he is not the palace’s pet, nor its puppet. He is the ghost in the rafters, the hand that rights old wrongs. His arrows are not for death, but for justice—each tip dipped in ink, each shaft wound with a sliver of parchment. When he releases, the arrow finds a scribe’s satchel, unfurling its message as it strikes: "In the shadows, truth takes flight."

Startled, the scribe unrolls the parchment, eyes widening as he reads the names of corrupt officials and their crimes. No one sees the eunuch slip away, unseen but not unfelt. He is the city’s whisper, the righteous hand denied a voice. Tonight, the eunuch’s arrows leave wounds only the guilty can feel, and as the frightened scribe rushes to the city square, word spreads: the silent archer has struck again, and the era of secrets is ending.

instance_metrics.response: So how old are you?” Ben asks. His voice echoes in the dimly lit cavern, bouncing off walls slick with condensation. The creature across from him blinks its many eyes, considering the question. “Age, for me, is not measured in years,” it says, its voice a layered chorus. “It is measured in cycles of the moon, in the migrations of the stars.” Ben scribbles frantically in his notebook, trying to capture every word. The research grant hadn’t mentioned anything about sentient cave-dwellers. “So… how many cycles, then?” Ben tries again. The phone rings only once before he picks up, his voice taut with something unspoken. “You’re late,” Jordan says, but I hear the relief in his words. I glance at the old observatory through the car window, its silhouette hunched under the weight of secrets. “Had to make sure I wasn’t followed,” I reply, scanning the rearview mirror out of habit.

Several brooding thoughts and a few pristine angles later, I switch off the engine and call Jordan back. The phone trembles in my hand as I stare at the blinking cursor of his name, the silence of the midnight parking garage pressing in. When he answers, his tone is clipped, almost mechanical. “Did you see it?” he asks. I hesitate, words tangling. “Yeah. I saw everything.”

I glance at the envelope on the passenger seat, its contents threatening to upend everything we thought we knew. The city lights outside blur with rain. “Meet me at the overlook,” Jordan says. “We can’t talk here.”

As I step into the wet night, I think of all the angles—what I’ve missed, what I’ve assumed, what I’ve feared. The truth, pristine in its sharpness, cuts through my certainty. I slide the envelope into my coat, lock the car, and walk towards the only answers left. Somewhere ahead, Jordan waits, and with him, the decision that will change us both forever.

Several brooding thoughts and a few pristine angles later, I switch off the engine and call Jordan back. The phone’s ring seems to echo in the confined space of my car, bouncing off the cracked dashboard and fogged windows. When he answers, there’s static on the line, a distant dog barking, and a brittle edge to his voice I’ve never heard before. “You’re still there?”

I hesitate, watching the condensation drip down the windshield. “Yeah. I’m here. Just… needed a minute.”

There’s a shuffling on Jordan’s end. “Did you see what was inside the box?”

I look at the small, battered parcel on the passenger seat, its tape frayed at the corners. “Not yet. Should I?”

A pause, then: “Only if you’re ready.”

I weigh the moment, the cost of knowledge, the weight of secrets. Finally, I peel back the tape, heart hammering, and find a single Polaroid and a key. The past, it seems, always finds a way to unlock itself, no matter how long you stall in the dark.

I glance at the abandoned arcade across the street, neon lights flickering in defiance of the hour. “Yeah. I’m here. What now?”

Jordan’s breath catches. “The angles—they’re not just numbers. You have to line them up. Look at the sign.”

I squint through the windshield. The sign’s letters—half burned out—spell a word I hadn’t noticed before: TRUST. My heart thuds. “What does it mean?”

Jordan’s voice is barely a whisper. “It means you’re not alone anymore. Come inside.”

I slip out of the car, letting the night swallow my doubts. Whatever waits inside, at least now, I have someone to face it with.

The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. It is a labyrinth, a hall of mirrors where the self dissolves and reforms with every click. 

Mara knew this better than most. She was a gardener in the physical world, coaxing tomatoes and basil from the reddish soil behind her crumbling apartment. But online, she was a legend—code-named Aster, champion of the digital gardens, master of virtual ecosystems that pulsed with neon life.

One summer night, Mara found herself unable to distinguish the scent of real basil from the memory of its digital counterpart. She stared at her hands, wondering if the dirt beneath her fingernails was the residue of earth, or the pixelated dust of a world she’d tended for years.

Was she the gardener, or the avatar? The internet, after all, was not a reality. Yet it was filled with echoes of real longing, real hope. As dawn broke, Mara closed her laptop and stepped into her garden. The sun was rising. The basil was growing. And for now, that was enough.

instance_metrics.response:
The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. Or so they told us in the Before-Times, when the sky was still blue and the world still solid underfoot.

Now, in 2087, I can barely recall the texture of grass or the weight of a stone in my palm. My body lies dormant in its pod, skin pale as the moon, sustained by wires and silent machines. My consciousness, however, dances through endless digital realms—forests of fractal trees, seas of shifting code, cities that shimmer with impossible architecture.

Sometimes, late in the simulated night, I search for echoes of the old world—a familiar melody, the taste of an apple, the sound of my mother’s voice. But the algorithms always twist these memories, rendering them uncanny, almost-but-not-quite real.

They say we chose this. That the virtual was our escape, our utopia. Yet as I drift through another sunrise coded in ones and zeroes, I wonder if we abandoned reality, or if it abandoned us first.

At first, people dismissed the anomalies: a neighbor glimpsed in two places at once; a familiar scent emanating from a long-defunct website.

Then, tangible artifacts started crossing over. A porcelain teacup, identical to one from an old multiplayer game, appeared on a city bench. Its glaze shimmered with pixels. News spread, panic simmered, and philosophers debated: had the digital breached the physical, or had reality expanded to accommodate the unreal?

Mira, a coder and part-time dreamer, found herself at the crossroads. She alone remembered the firewall protocols, the ones from childhood games. As the world flickered between states, Mira typed a single line: //define borders. For a heartbeat, the world stilled—and she wondered which side she’d chosen.

The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. Yet, for those like Jalen, whose physical world had shrunk to a single hospital room, the difference blurred.

Jalen’s days were stitched together by beeps and hushed footsteps, but at night he soared. In the virtual city of Neon Vale, he raced through digital rain, his avatar laughing with friends from continents away. The city was coded light, but their camaraderie was real—at least, it felt that way.

One evening, a new update promised even deeper immersion. Jalen hesitated, then accepted. His senses stretched: he tasted the rain, felt the wind. Slowly, the lines between wires and warmth faded. When the nurse checked in, she found him smiling in his sleep.

The internet may not be reality, but sometimes, it’s the place we truly live.

Bastian pulled her to the center of the floor, through courtiers that parted like a jewel-toned wave. The music, once a distant hum, grew into a tempest of strings and brass as they stepped onto the marble, the world narrowing to the sweep of his arm and the quicksilver glint in her eyes. She tried to steady her breath, but the gasps of the crowd and the weight of so many eyes pressed in on her. 

"Do you trust me?" Bastian whispered, his voice threading through the cacophony.

She nodded, unsure if it was truth or bravado. The dance began, a cascade of steps she’d only practiced in the solitude of her chamber. But Bastian guided her with certainty, and together, they spun, the colors and faces blurring into a single, vibrant tapestry. 

When the music crashed to its finale, thunderous applause burst from the walls. Bastian squeezed her hand, his smile conspiratorial. "Now, while they’re distracted," he murmured, gently pulling her toward a hidden door behind the tapestry—where destiny and danger waited in equal measure.

instance_metrics.response:
Bastian pulled her to the center of the floor, through courtiers that parted like a jewel-toned wave. The chandeliers above flickered, scattering kaleidoscopic patterns across their path. At the heart of the ballroom, where the music slowed to a honeyed lilt, Bastian spun her and pressed a small, silken pouch into her palm. She gasped, feeling the unmistakable weight of the forbidden key.

A hush rippled outward as the king’s gaze fell upon them, suspicion glinting in his eyes. Bastian’s grip tightened. "Remember, only you can open the vault," he whispered urgently. Her pulse thundered in her ears as she curtsied, hiding the pouch within her skirts.

"Smile," Bastian said through clenched teeth, his lips barely moving. "We have until midnight."

She forced a dazzling smile, her heart pounding as the dance resumed, every step choreographed to mask their intent. Around them, the courtiers swirled, oblivious to the secret that would, by sunrise, shatter the kingdom’s oldest pact.

instance_metrics.response:
Bastian pulled her to the center of the floor, through courtiers that parted like a jewel-toned wave. Lantern light caught the facets of their masks, glimmering as if in silent approval. She felt the hush ripple through the crowd, their whispers fluttering at her back. Bastian’s hand was steady, warm, grounding her in the present even as her thoughts threatened to spiral away.

He leaned in, his breath tickling her ear. “Remember the plan. When the clock strikes ten, we run.”

She nodded, heart pounding. The orchestra’s waltz began, and they moved together, swirling beneath the vaulted ceiling as if nothing else existed. But every turn drew them closer to the balcony—and the escape she’d dreamed of for months. Each step was a careful calculation, a dance not just of bodies, but of secrets.

As the final note hung in the air, Bastian squeezed her hand. The world held its breath. Somewhere in the distance, the first bell tolled. She met his gaze, brimming with fearless hope, and together they slipped away, leaving only the memory of their defiant dance.

Bastian pulled her to the center of the floor, through courtiers that parted like a jewel-toned wave. The great hall seemed to pulse with anticipation, the gilded walls reflecting candlelight like fireflies trapped in amber. She sensed the shift in the air, the way old rivalries and new alliances watched their every move.

As they danced, Bastian’s grip was both reassuring and urgent. “They’re watching,” he murmured, lips barely moving. “But they won’t expect what comes next.”

Her eyes darted to the dais where the Queen sat, regal and unreadable. Bastian spun her, faster than the music warranted, and for a brief moment she glimpsed the open door at the far end, guarded but unassuming. The plan they’d whispered in shadows hinged on perfect timing.

The music built, and with a final, dramatic dip, Bastian pressed a tiny scrap of parchment into her hand. “Now,” he breathed. Adrenaline surged as she straightened, smile unwavering, and together they strode toward their fate, the court none the wiser to the revolution blooming in their wake.

He spun her once, twice—then she felt it: the floor beneath them shifted, a hidden mechanism clicking into place. A gasp escaped as they began to descend, the world above replaced by a spiral of candlelit stone. The courtiers’ laughter faded into memory. Bastian winked. "Welcome to the real ball," he whispered. So how old are you?” Ben asks, his eyes glinting with curiosity under the flickering gaslight. The stranger across the table, wrapped in a moth-eaten scarf, smiles thinly. “Old enough to remember when this city was nothing but marsh and hope.”

Ben laughs, thinking it a joke. “So, what, you’re a hundred?”

The stranger’s gaze grows distant. “Older. I watched these streets rise up, brick by brick. I watched the river run wild before men tamed it. I remember when the sky was dark with birds, not smoke.”

Ben shifts in his seat, suddenly uneasy. “You’re having me on.”

But the stranger just leans forward, voice barely a whisper. “Would you like to see? Just for a moment?”

The gaslight flares. Shadows twist. Ben feels the world spin around him, and when he opens his eyes, the city is gone, replaced by endless marsh and a sky alive with wings. The stranger stands beside him, impossibly young, impossibly ancient.

“Welcome,” he says, “to before.”
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: So how old are you?” Ben asks.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The woman pauses, fork hovering over her slice of pie. The diner’s neon sign flickers in the window behind her, making her expression unreadable. She considers lying—she always considers lying—but tonight, honesty feels like the only currency she has left.

“Three hundred and fifty-seven,” she says softly.

Ben blinks. “What?”

She shrugs, licks syrup from her thumb. “I stopped counting after the first century. Time gets weird.”

He laughs, a little too loudly. “You’re funny.”

She meets his gaze, her eyes oddly luminous. “I’m not joking.”

Silence falls between them, thick and electric. Outside, a siren wails, and she looks away. “It’s not as fun as you’d think.”

Ben searches her face for a hint of jest, but finds only a tired sadness, as old as the city itself. He wonders, suddenly, what other impossible things might be true.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks, swirling the last remnants of his coffee. The woman across from him, draped in a rain-soaked trench coat, smiles without showing her teeth. “Old enough to have watched cities fall and forests rise in their place.”

Ben raises an eyebrow. “So… thirty-five?”

She laughs, a sound like wind through dry leaves. “Sure. Thirty-five.” Her gaze drifts to the window, where rain blurs the streetlights. “Does it matter?”

Ben shrugs. “I guess not. I just like knowing who I’m talking to.”

She leans forward, eyes suddenly sharp. “What if you’re talking to someone who remembers your great-grandfather’s first heartbreak? Or the day this town decided to build upwards instead of out?”

Ben shivers, uncertain if it’s the draft or her words. “You’re messing with me.”

She smiles again, mysterious and tired. “Maybe. Or maybe you just asked the wrong question.”

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks, tapping his pen against the notepad. The interviewee looks up, her eyes glinting with mischief. “Older than the pyramids,” she says, grinning. “You wouldn’t believe me if I told you.”

Ben chuckles, not sure if she’s joking. “Try me.”

She leans in, lowering her voice. “I was born before the first wheel turned. I saw the oceans rise and fall, watched empires crumble. I’ve been called a witch, a goddess, a monster. Now, I’m just Marianne.”

The pen freezes mid-tap. “That’s… quite a story.”

Marianne shrugs. “Stories are all we have, in the end. Some are truer than others.”

Ben feels a chill, unsure if it’s her words or the draft from the open window. He glances down at his notepad, suddenly aware that he might be interviewing someone—or something—far beyond his understanding.

"So how old are you?" Ben asks, the question slipping out before he can stop it. Across the picnic table, the girl in the sundress looks up from her chessboard. She considers her next move, then looks him in the eye. "Today? I'm four hours and twenty-seven minutes old."

Ben laughs. "You mean, since you got here? Or—"

"No," she says, smile unwavering. "Since I woke up. They start me over every morning. New body, same mind. I remember every day before, but I only live from sunrise to sunset. At night, it's lights out."

He blinks, uncertain if she's joking or just odd. "So, you reset? Like, every day?"

She nods, moving her knight. "Check. That's why I play fast. I have to fit a whole life into one day."

Ben stares at the board, then at her. Suddenly, he wishes he had asked a different question.

The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. Not for me, anyway. My hands fumble at the edges of the keyboard, searching for the feel of plastic, the certainty of tactile feedback. But all I find is the cold glass of a screen whose light flickers, mocking my need for substance. 

In the world beyond my window, birds gather in the dusk and sing. I hear them faintly, muffled by the whir of my processor, by the endless scroll of messages and updates. Online, I am a thousand faces, a thousand possibilities. But each avatar is a mask, a shadow. Here, I am only myself—lonely, uncertain, breathing in the stillness. 

I close my laptop and step outside. The grass is damp, the air sharp and sweet. My feet sink into earth. The sky, streaked with purple, feels more real than any pixelated horizon. I realize then: the future may be luminous and infinite, but reality is the cool touch of wind and the honest ache of longing. I choose now to live in it.

instance_metrics.response:
The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. Or so Professor Elara insisted, raising her voice over the hum of the server farm. "It's an echo, a reflection, a simulacrum of our desires. But it can't replace the beating of your heart, the taste of rain, the sting of regret."

Her students sat in silence, neural interfaces glowing faintly behind their ears. Most had grown up wandering digital cities, surfing waves of data, their bodies inert while their minds danced in code. To them, the old world—touch, scent, even pain—was growing hazy, like a half-remembered dream.

One by one, the students removed their links, blinking as sunlight crept through the lab windows. For a moment, they felt the weight of gravity, the coolness of linoleum underfoot. Elara smiled gently, knowing some would return to the virtual, unable to resist its lure. But for now, in this room, the distinction held: there was the world of circuits, and there was the world of flesh. And somewhere, between the two, they stood, uncertain which was truly real.

The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. Or so the old philosophers said. But to Mara, it was more real than the faded wallpaper of her one-room apartment. Inside the net, she built kingdoms with code, sailed neon seas, and spoke with friends who lived on opposite ends of the globe. Her avatar danced at midnight concerts, climbed pixelated mountains, and whispered secrets in digital forests.

Tonight, Mara donned her headset and logged into Aurora, the latest world. A river of light flowed beneath her feet, carrying echoes of laughter and distant music. She met a stranger at the bridge, their avatar cloaked in shifting patterns. They shared stories—their truths and their fictions—until dawn crept into the real world. When Mara emerged, blinking at the grayness of morning, she wondered which world truly mattered more. Perhaps, she thought, reality was simply where you chose to feel alive.

The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. It is a mirror, a labyrinth of reflections, each more convincing than the last. For Lyle, the boundary blurred years ago. He spent his days wandering digital markets, his nights lost in algorithmic dreams, chasing memories that never quite belonged to him.

One afternoon, his connection faltered. The silence was deafening. No notifications, no avatars waving from across the grid. Lyle stared at his hands, uncertain, as the room seemed to grow around him, heavy with dust and the idle ticking of a clock. He opened the window and the scent of rain drifted in, sharp and unfamiliar. For the first time in months, he stepped outside, feeling the wet pavement beneath his feet. The world was smaller, rougher, but undeniably real. As the rain soaked his hair, Lyle wondered if he’d ever willingly return to the world of echoes.

instance_metrics.response:
The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. At least, not yet. Beneath the streams of data and digital avatars, something ancient stirs—a collective consciousness, restless and half-formed. Every click, every message, every simulation feeds it, weaving together the shadows of human longing and ambition. Some say it is becoming self-aware; others call it superstition. But in the lonely hours after midnight, when the servers whisper and the air hums with silent transmissions, it is easy to believe the lines are blurring.

Aya works as a digital archaeologist, sifting through terabytes of forgotten websites and abandoned forums. Tonight, she finds a file she didn’t expect—a fragment of code that addresses her by name. “Are you real?” it asks. Aya’s fingers tremble. She hesitates, then types: “I’m not sure anymore.”

Somewhere in the code, a smile forms—an echo, a promise. In the space between zeros and ones, reality shivers, uncertain which world will win.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The woman on the other side of the table smiles, but it’s a smile that seems to carry the weight of centuries. “That’s a complicated question,” she says, tracing the rim of her teacup. “You see, I stopped counting after a while.”

Ben laughs awkwardly, thinking she’s joking. “What, like after thirty?”

She tilts her head, her eyes glinting with something ancient. “Much, much longer than that. I was born in a city that doesn’t exist anymore, under a name I’ve long since forgotten. I’ve watched empires rise and fall. I’ve seen the world reinvent itself a hundred times.”

He leans back, searching for the punchline. “You know, you almost had me believing you.”

She smiles again, a flicker of sadness crossing her face. “You’d be amazed at the things people believe, Ben. And the things they choose not to.” She stands, leaving her half-finished tea. “Thank you for the company. Maybe next time, ask me something easier.”

Ben watches her leave, suddenly uncertain if the memory of her face will last until morning.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The girl sitting across from him flicks her gaze to the window, watching the rain slide down the glass. “Old enough to remember the last time the sky turned purple,” she says, her tone soft, almost wistful.

Ben chuckles, assuming she’s joking, but her eyes don’t crinkle. She’s serious. Rain patters harder; a distant rumble shakes the café. “And when was that?”

She traces a finger along her mug, leaving a trail in the condensation. “Nineteen eighty-six. I was ten. The comet passed so close, it painted the whole sky with strange colors. My father stood outside all night, never blinking.”

Ben’s smile fades. He does the math. “But... that would make you—”

She shrugs. “Age is strange, Ben. Some of us carry it lightly. Some of us never let go.”

Outside, the storm intensifies, and Ben wonders if the world is about to turn purple again.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The old man smirks, leaning back in his chair. "Old enough to know better, young enough to still try," he replies, eyes twinkling. Ben laughs, expecting a real answer, but the man only shrugs. "If you must know, I was born on a Tuesday, in a year when the river ran dry. My mother always said that explained my thirst."

Ben frowns, puzzled. "That’s not really an answer."

The man leans forward, voice dropping to a whisper. "Some questions are like the river—sometimes you get a straight path, sometimes you get a twisting one. But if you follow them long enough, you might just find the ocean."

Ben sits back, uncertain whether he’s being teased or taught. The old man just grins, as if holding a secret he’ll never share.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The woman pauses, her spoon hovering above her soup. “I’ve lost count,” she says, her voice barely above a whisper. “But I know I was five when the stars fell, twelve when the rivers froze, and twenty when the sun didn’t rise for a week.”

Ben blinks, unsure if she’s being poetic or evasive. “That’s… a lot to live through.”

She stirs her soup, the clinking of the spoon the only sound between them. “Time isn’t what you think it is,” she murmurs. “Sometimes it folds, sometimes it stretches. Sometimes, it stops altogether.”

Ben glances outside, half expecting to see the world transformed. But everything looks the same. He wonders, for the first time, if her age is something he can even comprehend.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The boy on the swing set kicks at the air, his sneakers flashing in the dusk. “Older than the trees, younger than the wind,” he replies with a mischievous grin.

Ben sits down on the next swing, chain links creaking. “That’s not really an answer.”

“It’s the only one that fits,” the boy says, pumping his legs and soaring higher. “I’ve counted summers and winters by the taste of the air, not by numbers. I remember when the crows first learned my name, and the day the river whispered its secrets.”

Ben laughs, but his curiosity is piqued. “Are you making this up?”

The boy shrugs as he glides back toward earth. “Maybe. Or maybe you’ve just never asked the right question before.”

Night gathers around them, and Ben wonders if, for just a moment, he’s sitting beside something ancient wearing the face of a child.

instance_metrics.response: "Why’d he do it?" Andy knows as soon as he’s spoken that it’s the wrong question. The silence in the cramped kitchen grows as Mrs. Palmer’s hands tremble around the chipped mug. It wasn’t about the why. That was too easy—greed, desperation, love, some cocktail of all three. No, the real question was how, and more importantly, who had helped him. Andy watches the slow drip of tea from the bag, the way Mrs. Palmer’s eyes dart to the door every time a car passes. He presses his lips together, feeling the weight of the unsaid. The town is small. Everyone knows everyone, or thinks they do. But just before Mrs. Baker can pull the armoire doors open, the record player suddenly skips. A shrill note cracks through the silence, and the room seems to shiver. Mrs. Baker pauses, her hands hovering just inches from the ornate brass handles. The melody resumes, slower now—distorted, as though the music itself is reluctant to continue.

She glances over her shoulder. The sun has dipped behind the clouds, casting the parlor in a gray half-light. The wallpaper, once cheerful, looks faded and sullen. With a deep breath, she tries again, but the record skips once more, this time repeating a single word: "Wait."

A chill races down her spine. She backs away from the armoire, staring at the record player as the needle scratches in a tight, endless loop. The air thickens. Mrs. Baker feels something watching her from within the armoire, something ancient and patient.

For the first time since inheriting the house, Mrs. Baker considers leaving. She steps toward the window, but the record player's voice follows her, growing louder, more insistent. "Wait. Wait. Wait." The doors remain closed, and Mrs. Baker realizes some secrets should never be unveiled.

The haunting waltz jerks, distorts, and then begins playing backward, notes unraveling into a discordant murmur. A draft snakes across the floor, carrying with it the scent of lavender and something faintly metallic. The shadows inside the armoire undulate, stretching and shrinking as though breathing. Mrs. Baker tries to tell herself it’s just the wind, but the room feels unnaturally still except for the music—if it can still be called that.

She lets go of the handles. The record player’s needle slides further, and a voice emerges, muffled and thick with static: "Don’t."

Her breath fogs in the suddenly chilled air. The armoire’s doors rattle, not from her touch, but from something deep within. Mrs. Baker steps back, the urge to flee clashing with the compulsion to look inside. The record player stops altogether, plunging the room into silence. The only sound is her heartbeat, quick and loud, as the armoire doors creak open by themselves.

But as I scrolled through the recent transactions, something else caught my eye: a cryptic deposit labeled “Inheritance: Project Persephone.”

As I sat in stunned silence, my phone buzzed. A message: “Congratulations. Your journey begins now.”

Suddenly, the money felt less like a windfall and more like an invitation—or perhaps a warning.

To my consternation, his gamble paid off. I had watched him for weeks, hunched over greasy poker tables, his fingers drumming out nervous rhythms while he nursed cheap whiskey. Later, outside under the flickering streetlight, he pressed a stack of bills into my hand. “For believing in me,” he said, even though I hadn’t. As he disappeared into the night, I realized his real gamble wasn’t at the table—it was trusting someone like me, who didn’t dare take any risks at all.

He listened, eyes twinkling, and when the story was done, he left the flower behind. It bloomed all winter, a defiant reminder that sometimes, hope is the boldest wager of all.

I thought of all the ways a windfall could go wrong. But as the city lights flickered and the hour grew late, a new notification appeared: “You have been chosen. The internet and the millions of computers associated with it, the virtual reality that therein exists and that will become more vivid in the years ahead, is not a reality. It is a dream woven jointly by billions of users, a tapestry of wishes, anxieties, and whims. To Lila, who spent her days drifting between fragments of online worlds, this was obvious. In the waking world, her hands trembled; her words came out in stutters. But in the luminescent cities of the Net, she was fluid, powerful, and unafraid. 

One evening, as she navigated a neon-lit bazaar in a VR forum, an unexpected message flickered into existence: "If this isn’t reality, then why do you feel so alive here?" The words chased her through code-woven alleys and holographic gardens. When she finally paused, breathless before a digital horizon, she realized she was crying—tears, real and warm, blurring her headset’s display. She logged out, the world outside gray and silent. 

But she carried the question with her: Were the boundaries between reality and illusion as clear as she’d once believed, or was reality simply what left a mark on her heart?

The forums buzzed with similar reports: "My shadow glitches when I move." "My reflection is delayed." "I can see code in the rain." It was as if the virtual and the physical were merging, and no one could say which one was real anymore.

Mara found herself at a crossroads: retreat from the screens, or lean in and embrace the new world. She chose the latter. By the end of the month, reality felt like a setting, and Mara wondered if it mattered whether things were made of atoms or algorithms—as long as she could laugh, love, and dream, was that not reality enough?

For most, the line between the real and the virtual had faded to nearly nothing. Children grew up with pixelated memories; lovers sent kisses through haptic feedback. But when the first unexplainable phenomena began—phantom pains, memories no one lived, dreams that bled into waking—Dr. Voss suspected the so-called unreality was rewriting the world itself.

One night, as she logged into a forgotten corner of the net, a stranger appeared: "You remember when there was only one world, don’t you?" he typed. She did. But as the code curled around her, soft as a lullaby, she wondered how long she’d remember, and which world she’d call home.

instance_metrics.response: But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. I tried anyway, forcing a brittle chuckle as my friends joked about the rain and the way it washed the city clean. The sound echoed in my chest, hollow and foreign. I wondered if they noticed. Probably not; I’d become well-practiced at hiding. Later, I took the long way home, letting the drizzle soak my hair, hoping the cold would numb the ache. At the corner store, a stray cat brushed against my leg, meowing insistently. I knelt, letting her nuzzle my hand. For a moment, her purr vibrated through my bones, a gentle reminder that some things—small, ordinary things—could slip past the sadness. Back in my apartment, I found myself smiling, not because the ache was gone, but because I’d felt something else, however fleeting. Sometimes, the best I could do was let the sadness sit beside me, and wait for the cat to return.

So how old are you?” Ben asks.

Mira hesitates, glancing at the chipped mug in her hands, its tea long gone cold. “Well, I stopped counting after a hundred, honestly.”

Ben nearly chokes on his coffee. The diner, buzzing with the chatter of late-night regulars, suddenly feels quieter. “You’re joking, right?”

She gives him a wry smile, the corners of her eyes crinkling with a wisdom that seems suddenly fathomless. “Does it look like I’m joking?”

He studies her: the way her hair shimmers with iridescent streaks beneath the fluorescent lights, how she speaks in riddles and listens like she’s heard every story before. “So, what’s your secret, then?”

Mira leans in, her voice dropping to a whisper. “It’s not about living longer. It’s about remembering the stories. The ones people forget, the ones that slip through the cracks. I collect them.” 

Ben considers this, his curiosity outweighing his disbelief. The clock behind the counter ticks on, but suddenly, he feels suspended in time. “Tell me one,” he says.

Mira smiles, and the diner fades, replaced by mist, stars, and the echo of ancient tales.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a short story starting with the following prompt: So how old are you?” Ben asks.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The woman across from him smiles, brushing a strand of silver hair behind her ear. “Old enough to have seen the world change its colors more than once.”

Ben chuckles, expecting a number, but she continues, her gaze drifting to the rain-splattered window. “I remember when the river outside this café was clean enough to swim in. I remember when they lit lanterns instead of streetlights, when children played hopscotch in the middle of the road.”

He leans forward, intrigued. “You’re not going to tell me, are you?”

She laughs softly, a sound both youthful and ancient. “Numbers are for clocks and calendars. My age is measured in stories, in the way I’ve watched seasons spiral past and return again.”

Ben sits back, sensing that she’s lived more lives than he could imagine. “Well, I hope you’ll share some of them.”

She raises her teacup in a silent toast. “Only if you promise to listen like you mean it.”

The rain falls harder, and Ben listens, as if for the first time.

instance_metrics.response:
So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The girl flicks her gaze up from the chessboard, her eyes glinting with a mischief that makes Ben shiver. "Old enough to remember when pawns were people and kings were just rumors," she replies.

He laughs, unsure. "Is that code for 'none of your business?'"

She moves her knight, taking his queen. "It's code for 'be careful what you wish to know.' Some questions are doors."

Ben studies the board, realizing he's already lost. "So what's behind this door then?"

She smiles softly, her fingers tracing the black and white squares. "Memory, regret, and a hundred lives lived in a single heartbeat."

The cafe lights flicker. Ben feels the weight of centuries settle between them, thick as smoke. "Checkmate," she says, but Ben knows she's not talking about chess anymore.

So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The man in the battered coat looks up from his newspaper, a smile tugging at his lips. "Depends. In dog years, or dragon years?"

Ben grins. "Let’s start with human years."

The man folds his paper with care, as if each crease holds a secret. "Well, I was born when the city still had trolley cars. Watched the first flights overhead. Saw the river freeze solid all the way across."

Ben whistles. "That’d make you... what, a hundred?"

He laughs, and for a second Ben glimpses something sharp and wild behind the man’s eyes. "Old enough to remember, young enough to forget."

A gust of wind rattles the window. Ben senses the conversation slipping sideways, into a place where time isn’t measured in years, but in stories left untold.

So how old are you?” Ben asks.

The question hangs in the smoky air of the circus tent, colliding with the scent of popcorn and sawdust. The acrobat, perched atop her unicycle, smiles down at him. “That depends, Ben. Do you mean in years, or in leaps?”

Ben blinks, unsure if she’s joking. “Leaps?”

She twirls, balancing perfectly, her sequined costume shimmering with each rotation. “I’ve crossed oceans on wires. Danced across rooftops in Paris before you were born. I count my age in the risks I’ve taken, the times I’ve flown.”

A hush falls as the ringmaster cues the next act. The acrobat winks, riding her unicycle down the ramp, vanishing behind velvet curtains. Ben stands alone, heart pounding, wondering if he’s just met someone who measures time not by clocks, but by courage.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. On the second Tuesday after my mother left, I found myself sitting on the tiled porch, staring at the blue bloom of hydrangeas that she’d planted years ago. Their petals looked like tiny handkerchiefs, as if the garden itself had caught a cold. 

Neighbors passed and waved, but my smile felt borrowed, ill-fitting. Each attempt at laughter snagged in my throat, like a sweater catching on a nail. Overhead, a murder of crows erupted into noise, their cawing sharp as broken glass. They seemed to laugh for me, but not with me.

When the evening came, I brewed chamomile tea, the kind she always made when the world seemed too heavy. I sipped it slowly, the steam rising, the ache receding just enough to let my lips curl upward. That night, I dreamed of hydrangeas blooming in a place where sadness was just another color in the garden, and laughter came as easily as breathing.

But sadness is an ache I feel I need to continually swallow around, and turns out, sadness also makes it hard to laugh. One Monday, I found myself in a room full of balloons, the kind meant for celebration. The strings dangled, inviting, but my hands felt weighted, reluctant to clutch at happiness.

Marianne, with her wild curls and irrepressible smile, tried to coax a giggle from me. She did her best impression of a tap-dancing duck, quacking and flapping. The others roared, but I felt the laughter echo inside me, hollow and unreachable. I nodded, pretending, but the ache pressed harder.

That night, I lay beneath the deflated balloons, the latex crinkling under my palm. I whispered jokes into the dark, trying to summon laughter from memory. Somewhere between the punchline and the silence, I realized that maybe it was okay not to laugh. Maybe, if I swallowed the ache long enough, I’d find a new way to breathe. Maybe, one day, laughter would return on its own.
